topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/553734f163687228b1650600#post_553734f163687228b1650600
Question. I havent read one piece in while. What makes its story different from the similar length plots of naruto and bleach.

I remember it just basically being a bunch of fun adventure stories leading into one another. Does it still do that?
topics.author: 500757fd7f123b75a90003b1

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/553735fe6368722f45630100#post_553735fe6368722f45630100

topics.author: 500b587e7f123b1f230014a9

topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/553736526368723bc58a0600#post_553736526368723bc58a0600
Well the answer is simple. Fun. And good writing. Basically in One Piece I legitimately care about the characters I'm supposed to care about. And One Piece isn't as rigid in it's setting. Oda has set up One Piece where virtually anything can happen and it makes sense. Remember, this is a series in which a Rubber Man regularly converses with a reindeer who is also a doctor, a speedo wearing cyborg, and a skeleton with an afro.

Yep.
